heat/engine/resources/openstack/neutron/.message: I guess it would only go in victoria 15.0.0

Hi Rabi, 
Thanks for review comments. 
updated version to 15.0.0.
same here.. I'm not sure why we need this attribute though.

I was not questioning the need for the resource 'property'. The 'attribute' word is little different in the context of heat as compared to neutron. The question was whether this heat resource attribute is expected to be referenced in another resource etc. By default it would be false and if you set it you can get the value from the property.

Anyway, we've them for many other things. So it's ok.

Hi Rabi, 
Thanks for review comments. 
1) updated version to 15.0.0.
2) The attribute PROPAGATE_UPLINK_STATUS is needed and critical for SR-IOV use case. SR-IOV users and operators can use this attribute in heat template to enable SR-IOV VF link status reflecting underlay PF status, and therefore, have an accurate view of SR-IOV port status. 
As noted in related netron-lib commit: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/571821/
and also https://review.opendev.org/#/c/571899/
"
This attribute indicates if the state of the port will follow
the state of its parent port. The first use case of this attribute
is SR-IOV. If it is a VF port, setting this attribute can make
the VF link state follow the state of the PF. In the future,
this attribute might be reused for trunk/subports as well.
"
3) As showed in https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/neutron/stein.html. This feature is fully 
support in neutron for SR-IOV. And the only missing piece is heat support for progate_uplink_status feature. And this is the purpose of this commit.

in normal python you should not use == and None
you shoudl do x is None

None is a uniary type in pythons type system.
there is only ever one instanc eof the None object and you are ment to do comparisons with it via an identity check
i.e. X is None rather then an equality check x == None

that said this si part of the sqlalcamy dsl and not standard python and we are not sure if that support "x is None" in this context to generate sql that will check if the column is Null.

my understanding is that sqlalceamy reflecting over this statement to generate the sql query so it would have to expclitly support both forms so the pythonic transformation of == to is might break it hence the need for # noqa
@Sean I agree with you, x is None is better than x==None, but I am not sure sqlalceamy whether can accept x == None and x is None, I think keep current status is security.

The idea is that this section adds additional steps around the generic series-upgrade steps to handle the peculiarities of OpenStack Charms as well as percona-cluster itself.
Can you clarify that the downtime should be control plane only? When done correctly, the compute, storage, and networking should remain fully functional throughout the process.

This is going to be overly restrictive, there are monitoring charms as well. Just as an example, this is one of the physical hosts behind serverstack:

ceph-osd/3*                  active    idle   8
  bcache-tuning/3            active    idle
nova-compute-ephemeral/8     active    idle   8
  bcache-tuning/4*           active    idle
  ganglia-node/15            active    idle
  neutron-openvswitch/0*     active    idle
  nrpe/0                     active    idle
  ntp/0*                     active    idle

When we say colocated, we generally are not referring to application subordinates (so, everything in the example above, or hacluster, etc), but things where two independent applications are on the same host (hulk smashed), an example that we do expect being ceph-osd and nova-compute

This is a note about workload availability during a series upgrade. In essence, the things that the charm provides should, if possible / necessary, be migrated to a different node during the upgrade.

What this would look like for nova-compute (one example in the doc):

juju upgrade --prepare 0 bionic
Disable the hypervisor in OpenStack so new instances don't schedule there
Evacuate all instances on the hypervisor
## dot the series upgrade!!!
Enable the hypervisor in OpenStack

At the end of the process (assuming everything worked as expected), no tenant VM will have any downtime, the nova-compute units will have upgraded, and the last one done will have no tenant VMs on it (new instances will tend to the unloaded ones so this will re-balance over time).

These are all optional steps!!!!!

The series upgrade will complete perfectly fine without doing the disable/evacuate/enable bits; however, the tenant VMs will be down during the reboot.

I'm seeing a bit of conflicting info, but apt full-upgrade is the right command for CLI use.  apt-get is still recommended for scripting as it's more machine-friendly output-wise (no progress bar ansi codes, etc) but this doc says apt is the newer utility and dist-upgrade is an alias for full-upgrade.  I'm good with full-upgrade, it's a bare "upgrade" that is concerning, as you need the dist/full- prefix to remove deprecated packages that are no longer needed and were not specifically user-installed.

So, I think the apt full-upgrade with juju ssh makes sense, but line 280 should be updated to apt-get because it's using juju run and the target of line 280 is a non-interactive upgrade process.

releasenotes/notes/ussuri-prelude-e7f5a1.message:
I strongly suggest to enhance that by reusing this:
  - Streamlined configuration of external Ceph integration, making it easy to
    go from Ceph-Ansible-deployed Ceph cluster to enabling it in OpenStack.

tests/tests.yaml.message: I don't think that this charm should need to run all of the Ceph tests, as changes to this charm can't break the internal Ceph functioning; however, there should be a new test that verifies that the a volume added to Cinder is placed on Ceph

Chris, that is exactly what my intention is:  verify that the ceph portion of this deployment is behaving as we expect, based on the same assertions that we run against a ceph deployment.  I don't see why that is superfluous, and I don't agree that is an indicator that the ceph tests are overly broad.

"Does the toaster make toast?" is the basic black-box question we're asking.  And we expect the answer to be "yes" before we move on to assert cinder-ceph integration pieces in a similar way.

If running the Ceph tests is verifying that it works with Cinder, then I'd suggest that the CephTest is overly broad and should be refactored. I think it would be good for the Ceph charms to have test coverage for validating the ceph functionality, and another CephOpenStackTest (naming things is hard) that would validate Ceph + OpenStack. This new test would be a good thing to include in OpenStack service tests with Ceph, but CephTest should just validate Ceph things (in my mind)
I agree. Additionally I think test_499_ceph_cmds_exit_zero was interesting to keep as well.

I tend to disagree with the former; running the ceph tests verifies that cinder is working with ceph.  I understand your reasoning, I just think that it gives us another test/integration test point.  The new test that verifies a volume is added to cinder is useful, though.

deploy-guide/source/features/distributed.message:
It's whenever GlanceBackend: rbd is set AND NovaEnableRBDBackend: true is set.

Easy way to avoid this is to not set NovaEnableRBDBackend: true in parameter_defaults (i.e global scope) by using t-h-t/environments/ceph-ansible/ceph-ansible-per-role.yaml instead of ceph-ansible.yaml.


We can then set the param per role e.g 

ComputeParameters:
  NovaEnableRBDBackend: true

...which will not enable image conversion.

And we don't even need to do this as there are already roles with the default set - ComputeLocalEphemeral and ComputeRBDEphemeral

Thanks for reviewing this Ollie.

 > It's whenever GlanceBackend: rbd is set AND NovaEnableRBDBackend:
 > true is set.

True. Because the deployment uses environments/ceph-ansible/ceph-ansible.yaml this was implicit but I'll make the statement explicit in the next patch set. I agree.

 > Easy way to avoid this is to not set NovaEnableRBDBackend: true in
 > parameter_defaults (i.e global scope) by using t-h-t/environments/ceph-ansible/ceph-ansible-per-role.yaml
 > instead of ceph-ansible.yaml.
 > 
 > 
 > We can then set the param per role e.g
 > 
 > ComputeParameters:
 > NovaEnableRBDBackend: true
 > 
 > ...which will not enable image conversion.
 
That doesn't seem easier. We can document that the two vars are getting AND'd and then tell the user that because of that you can set it per role instead of globally and then require them to list every role. But that seems like extra work which relies on the AND'ing. Why not just enable conversion or disable conversion by directly setting the image_import_plugins list? That seems simpler to me and works regardless of what roles they have.

 > And we don't even need to do this as there are already roles with
 > the default set - ComputeLocalEphemeral and ComputeRBDEphemeral

In this document we're deploying Ceph and ComputeHCI (or just Compute) at central so we want both NovaEnableRBDBackend:true and GlanceBackend:rbd. If someone isn't using Ceph at central then they wouldn't use this doc, they'd just use :doc:`distributed_compute_node`.

The pattern in this doc is to upload any image to central and then run it where it's needed. Let's show them how to put it in central with or without conversion and tell them why they'd want one or the other and let them decide what makes sense for them. 

Because "openstack image create with a qcow2" results in a qcow2 image being stored (even with the conversion enabled) I think we've established that enabling the conversion is orthogonal. I'll document that too. In other words:

 'openstack image create' qcow -> ends up in qcow
 'qemu-img convert' to raw then 'openstack image create' -> ends up in raw
 'glance image-create-via-import' qcow image -> ends up in raw

Let's see if everyone's ok with the next patch set.

I think the code is not enabling automatically image_conversion in glance-api unless both glance *and* nova on that same stack are configured to use rbd [1]

Shall we just set NovaEnableRbdBackend:false in the central site?

> I think the code is not enabling automatically image_conversion in
 > glance-api unless both glance *and* nova on that same stack are
 > configured to use rbd [1]

True. The deployment is passing environments/ceph-ansible/ceph-ansible.yaml so they're both set.

 > Shall we just set NovaEnableRbdBackend:false in the central site?

I don't like that option since glance is deployed at central so you'd want to use the rbd nova backend.

I wouldn't suggest messing with GlanceBackend, if GlanceBackend is not rbd conversion is not enabled anyway

Instead I would just say "when deploying the first stack, set NovaEnableRbdBackend to false or override image_import_plugins"

Then in the snippet I would show both

> I wouldn't suggest messing with GlanceBackend, if GlanceBackend is
 > not rbd conversion is not enabled anyway
 
done.

 > Instead I would just say "when deploying the first stack, set
 > NovaEnableRbdBackend to false or override image_import_plugins"

done. 
 
 > Then in the snippet I would show both

I like the snippet as it is. Overriding NovaEnableRbdBackend with an example shouldn't be necessary because it's a boolean THT param and I expect people will only override image_import_plugins if they want to keep NovaEnableRbdBackend true.
ok but if you don't want to put it in the snippet, then I'd be explicit and say "set NovaEnableRbdBackend: false" instead of "override accordingly"

and also set this to true in role params for every compute role used on that stack (otherwise nova will use local ephemeral). This is why I'm suggesting we set it to true by default in all of the HCI roles (e.g like we do for the tuned profile)

> > ways to do it. Can we just remove "set novarbd:false or" from
 > this
 > > doc since it's controversial and not absolutely necessary.
 > 
 > We can either document how to set this on a per-role basis, or on a
 > per stack basis. Right now we are somewhere in-between which isn't
 > valid (at least not complete).

This section of the document is only about one stack and it's central. They can set it differently when they do other stacks.

 > However I expect we will have to come back and revisit this once we
 > want to combine local ephemeral and RBD ephemeral at the same site
 > (novarbd must be set per-role in that case). Also for older release
 > where we don't have multi-stack we can only use the per-role
 > approach.
 > 
 > That is why I'm suggesting we just go down the per-role route to
 > begin with.
 
I thought we agreed not to do per-role yesterday. 

 > > > We would also need to set GlanceShowMultipleLocations: true
 > >
 > > Done on 457 and 653 of the next patch set.
 > 
 > Can we just set it in the ceph-ansible.yaml environment file?

I would really rather not. ceph-ansible.yaml is used all over the place in non-dcn deployments. I don't think we should submit a patch to change that and I'm not encouraging users to directly modify it either. Instead I think it's an override that should be passed when needed and overrides concerning glance in this document are on lines 457 and 653.
I don't think this is needed because when launching the deployment of the DCN site, if it uses ceph and you pass ceph-ansible, NovaEnableRbdBackend will be set to true for that stack

I'm talking about computes in the central site.

We would also need to set GlanceShowMultipleLocations: true

> > I'm talking about computes in the central site.
 > 
 > I think we're all talking about computes at the central site. This
 > portion of the document is only concerned with computes at the
 > central site and in this scenario ceph is always deployed at
 > Central. If Ceph wasn't deployed at Central then the reader would
 > follow :doc:`distributed_compute_node`.
 > 
 > I want to avoid being prescriptive here. I'm showing them a few
 > ways to do it. Can we just remove "set novarbd:false or" from this
 > doc since it's controversial and not absolutely necessary. I've
 > stated how things work and the reader can deduce that they can set
 > it false if they want to.
 > 
 > > We would also need to set GlanceShowMultipleLocations: true

I meant that this would be necessary on the central stack if NovaEnableRbdBackend: false. Latest patch does not mention setting NovaEnableRbdBackend: false so it's irrelevant now.

 > 
 > Done on 457 and 653 of the next patch set.

I don't think that was strictly necessary as the logic to enable it automatically checks for rbd when there is multi-backend, but can't hurt to make it explicit I guess

> ways to do it. Can we just remove "set novarbd:false or" from this
 > doc since it's controversial and not absolutely necessary.

We can either document how to set this on a per-role basis, or on a per stack basis. Right now we are somewhere in-between which isn't valid (at least not complete).

However I expect we will have to come back and revisit this once we want to combine local ephemeral and RBD ephemeral at the same site (novarbd must be set per-role in that case). Also for older release where we don't have multi-stack we can only use the per-role approach.

That is why I'm suggesting we just go down the per-role route to begin with.

 > > We would also need to set GlanceShowMultipleLocations: true
 > 
 > Done on 457 and 653 of the next patch set.

Can we just set it in the ceph-ansible.yaml environment file?

> I'm talking about computes in the central site.

I think we're all talking about computes at the central site. This portion of the document is only concerned with computes at the central site and in this scenario ceph is always deployed at Central. If Ceph wasn't deployed at Central then the reader would follow :doc:`distributed_compute_node`. 

I want to avoid being prescriptive here. I'm showing them a few ways to do it. Can we just remove "set novarbd:false or" from this doc since it's controversial and not absolutely necessary. I've stated how things work and the reader can deduce that they can set it false if they want to.

 > We would also need to set GlanceShowMultipleLocations: true

tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-deploy-dep.message:
wait_for_stack_ready() exits[1] only when you've a overcloud stack event with either *_COMPLETE/*_FAILED status.

If you remove this task your deploy command would get stuck for ever if for some reason heat_engine is restarted and with convergence heat, stack status stays IN_PROGRESS after restart.

This seems ike a bug in previous versions too. We seem to have added tasks in the deploy_plan workflow[2] to check for stack status till timeout, but never used it from the client.

My initial plan was to add event polling in ansible itself as part of retry logic, but it seems non-trivial.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/utils.py#L940

[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/stable/train/workbooks/deployment.yaml#L217

This role is used by many jobs hosted by many zuul instances (i know at least 4) and it would be a maintenance nightmare to have to define this variable on each of these places. Also when docker will fix the issue, we will have undo the override in 10-20 places. Why to overcomplicate it?
I meant the url and it's default value would be better stored as a role variable and documented in the README.
Then should this be performed only when the above when predicate isn't true?

No, this must continue, as it will install docker-ce. The workaround is to pre-install an older version of containerd.io so the normal installation of docker-ce will encounter the conflict.

The same can be achieve with yum install --nobest but our code is using package and not even the yum/dnf ansible module have support for --nobest option.

specs/keystone/ongoing/role-check-bodyke.message: You have a specific example for this case, but I can imagine some badly-designed API could enforce policy based on any number of inappropriate keys, such as headers, or the contents of an uploaded object. Or perhaps the API isn't a JSON API. We can't predict all these cases.

The nova project is just one of quite a lot of OpenStack services, and keystone is even often used for non-OpenStack services, this is why I worry about trying to take nova's weird corner case and turn it into a one-size-fits-all solution.

I'm not sure if this will be a silver bullet, but nova has a specification proposed that details, extensively, the work they'd like to do to clean up their policy enforcement.

I don't know if microversions helps fix the in-body key API issues, but that could be a discussion to have in that specification. Also, if that work gets done, I would be really curious to see the reaction from operators and users since it would be moving nova in the right direction policy-wise. Maybe we assist them with that effort where we can and revisit this when the dust settles and before we start making a complicated change to queue off of request body information.
Adam, if this (somehow magically) wasn't a problem for nova, would there still be a need for this?
Link to the nova specification under review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547850/

Maybe a better title is Constrained Roles or Constrained Delegation or Constrained Tokens or even Least Privileges.

This link to the blueprint is broken. Can you fix it please
Done.  Note the this is an artifact of the revie, but the BP is there:  https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/subset-tokens
This draft is not addressing the problem of interception. It is addressing the issue of Least Privileges, in that it wants a token to be constrained rather than having full privileges.
You need to make clear whether this feature is for delegation of privileges to a third party or simply a user swapping a token for a less privilege one for himself
Removed this last paragraph, as I think that was making things less clear.  It is only the "request for  self" that is addressed in this spec.
No. Just Perform.  The token provides all access.
I think there will be a UX trade-off, which requiring user to know exactly which roles and which endpoints to request.
Beyond the scope of this spec.  Ability to map from actions back to roles or endpoints is parallel to this.

the endpoint filtering doesn't provide security and really isn't worth adding in. the cost of caching/CPU/etc makes endpoint filtering not really worth it at any real scale.

the role subset is worth continuing.
THis does not actually require endpoint filtering to be effective.  It just means you can get a token for glance without also exposing access to nova APIs as well.
To maintain the size of Fernet tokens, the request should have only a single role, although, via role inference rules, the token may then have multiple roles associated.
User has no idea what roles he needs to perform a given operation. Making this up to the user is the wrong direction IMO. Operators configure/change policies and users have no idea about it
How does it know what roles are needed for performing a given workflow? Does it even know what the workflow is supposed to be run with that token (e.g spin up an instance) ?

specs/keystone/ongoing/subset-tokens.rst.message: I thought we already discussed this route in Vancouver. What was the outcome?

So the workflow of this requires a user to:

- know the required role of an operation in another service
- ask keystone for a token scoped to a specific role on a specific project
- pass the token to the service

How is this going to be effectively used by horizon or other clients? Right now horizon will get a token scoped to a project for all operations a user wants to do within that project. This will be a pretty big change for clients to implement and I'm wondering what their feedback is.
Horizon should use an unscoped token for maintaint the user session, and token scoped as narrowly as possible for the operations requested.
Depending on the intended use case, this could be partially solved with application credentials or trusts.

oslo_policy/shell.py.message:
Rather than doing this, could you use a boolean option (Look for 'store_true') in the argparse docs [1].

Later: I see we already are doing something else for '--is-admin' so I guess we want to be consistent here. You can ignore this.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/argparse.html
We usually have options like --namespaced and --no-namespaced set up to use the store_true and store_false actions, instead of requiring the user to pass true/false as an argument to the option.
I agree, although as Stephen pointed out this is an unfortunate existing pattern in this CLI. Does anyone know if we can change that without breaking existing callers who pass a parameter?

Oh, sorry, I missed Stephen's earlier review comment.

Frankly, I would rather use the more widely standard pattern here and come back and fix those other options later.

Yeah, what Ben said. I figured local consistency was better, even if it meant doing things awkwardly like this.

> Does anyone know if we can change that without breaking existing callers who pass a parameter?

In theory, we could rework '--is-admin' to make its argument optional (nargs='?') but that's an extra change and I'm not sure what happens if '--is-admin' isn't the last option. Would it consume the next option in the list?

I think we want this to default to True, based on the commit message and my reading of the previous version. The existing behavior assumes namespacing, but because BoolOpt defaults to None this will evaluate as false so we'll start skipping the : check.

Previously this was handled in a roundabout way by assuming anything except the explicit string "false" was true, which I think means either None or "" would have evaluated as true. I'm not sure which argparse would default to, but it doesn't matter.

Off the top of my head I'm not sure whether BoolOpt allows you to specify an explicit value on the CLI or if it's just a flag. If the latter we might need to invert the logic and call this not_namespaced or something.
